At 16 hours I had had enough: I HATED this game and logged in to write a scathing review. And yet, 160+ hours later, I‚Äôm on my second playthrough, purchased the previous DOS, and am writing a positive review while listening to the OST. What happened?! This whole misunderstanding started with an impulse purchase and a single, overlooked, very tiny, yet crucial word: tactical.  I had finished a turn based RPG and was in the mood for another, when I saw that DOS2 had just been released. I almost never buy a game at launch, but the trailer looked great, Metacritic boasted a ludicrously high score along with dozens of tasty blurbs, and the whole game had that tantalizing sheen that anything new has. The only negative thing I found at the time was a single review that ranted about rage-quitting the game. Who rage-quits a RPG, I thought at the time?  I took a risk, and was immediately entranced: the character creation was complex and intriguing, the opening story and fight sequences were engaging, everything seemed so promising that I hardly noticed the dreaded word I had overlooked earlier. After a while, however, things took a dark turn for the worse. I kept getting beaten, and beaten badly; my frustration mounted; the world was turning against me; nothing was helping; I felt completely powerless‚Ä¶and then‚Ä¶rage quit.  Amidst the guilt, confusion and shame, I decided to sit down and actually read through all those glowing reviews; what was I missing here? And then I finally noticed it, that dreaded word: tactical. I do not play tactical RPG‚Äôs, never have, assumed I never would, and was unprepared for what I was experiencing here. It‚Äôs not that I don‚Äôt play tactical games, but I like to keep my genres separate, and was clearly not expecting this.  I play games for different reasons. Some for immersion, others for adrenaline, mental stimulation, relaxation, storytelling, etc. For me, RPG‚Äôs equal immersion; that‚Äôs what I expect, why I play them. The acts of becoming a character, building them up, leading them through decisions and adventures, customizing them, engaging in their world, these are creative acts. Tactics, on the other hand, are left-brained; strategy; detached, clinical, chess-like, requiring a different mindset. When I crave that, I‚Äôll play a strategy game. But to combine the two is counter to what I want from a role playing experience.  So, after hours of trying really hard to like this game, only to die repeatedly in the process, I had officially given up. This simply wasn‚Äôt for me. Just as I was about to uninstall, though, something happened, and to this day I still don‚Äôt know what it was. For some mysterious reason, I decided to launch DOS2 one last time. I began to play, I mean really play. By the time I finally escaped Fort Joy, I realized something: this game is getting better; a LOT better. And my negative review? Well, suddenly it was becoming a positive one.  It was still no cake-walk, but my feelings began to change when I altered my play style. Up to then I had been approaching it as any other RPG; and it finally sunk in that I simply can‚Äôt do that. I couldn‚Äôt run blindly into battles, dash wildly about the landscape, race through dialogue; instead I had to slow down, take nothing for granted, become obsessed with details. I also had to redefine what it meant to lose. I had to go into each fight knowing my characters wouldn‚Äôt survive, instead using the chance to study the enemies, how they play, how I react, and how it all unfolds, so when I reload, I can play the fight ‚Äúfor real‚Äù and have a plan in mind. This meant that I had to play most battles upwards of half a dozen times before I got it right; but when things did click into place, it was a beautiful feeling.  Still, I do have a few remaining criticisms, the biggest being the quest and map design. Confusing, unforgiving, unhelpful, oblique, unfair‚Ä¶are but a few of the words I‚Äôd use to describe them. Simply put, it‚Äôs just way too easy to stumble into things you‚Äôre not ready for. As for the quests, dialogues and journal entries are misleading, key information is frequently given out of order, or omitted altogether, way too may red-herrings, and the supposed freedom to tackle a quest multiple ways doesn‚Äôt work if you dare to do things out of order. If you‚Äôre looking for guidance, look to Google, for you will find none in-game. People might tout this as a feature: it doesn‚Äôt hold your hand, they cheer. Indeed. There is no hand-holding, which would be fine if the quest design didn‚Äôt keep tripping over its own two feet.  The map layout is so cluttered and dense that basically each and every pixel is trying to kill you. At first I felt this was infuriatingly random; after a while I did start to pick up on the clues, and was able to avoid such missteps, but it was a lesson learned the hard way. There‚Äôs nothing wrong with this, but I‚Äôm used to other games which balance the levels with your current abilities; you can freely wander where you‚Äôre likely to survive, and prevented from getting in over your head. But DOS2 is more than happy to let you get in over your head. The key is to recognize your own limits, knowing the game won‚Äôt do it for you.  As far as audio/visual design, this is single-handedly some of the best art-direction I‚Äôve seen in a game. The detail given to the environments is so rich that the world feels alive in ways that other games could only dream of. Rivellon is LIVED IN; it exists, it‚Äôs lush, and rich in the most unexpected ways. By comparison, all other RPG worlds feel dead, like stage sets populated by mere mannequins. Every square inch of DOS2 is simply bursting with life. The audio is top notch too. I just love the soundtrack. Works brilliantly in game, and is great outside as well. The voices are an absolute treat, too. I don‚Äôt know where they found these actors, but their delivery is infectious. The dialogue is already good, but you can tell how much they really dug their characters, the way they rolled the words around and added such flavor to the lines, making each and every one, from the biggest hero down to the lowest fish monger, feel 100% unique. Seriously, is there an award for best video game ensemble performance?  Regarding immersion, even after coming to terms with a tactical RPG, I was never able to feel that I was part of the world of Rivellon, or that the character I was playing was really me, or that the decisions I made mattered. The story didn‚Äôt haunt me between gaming sessions, I can barely remember most of it now, to be honest. And yet, I‚Äôve had so many individual experiences, so many moments that feel were hand-crafted just for me, so many surprises (both by what I could get away with, and just how flexible the game mechanics really are), that I do feel an emotional, as well as intellectual, connection. This game has given me memories of frustration, true, but also memories of joy, surprise, amazement, wonderment, suspense, excitement, and mischievousness. In spite of the many miraculous accomplishments of this game, it is for these memories that I thank Larian the most.  So now we‚Äôve arrived. That‚Äôs how a sternly negative review, over the course of a few hundred unexpected hours of play, morphed into a shout of praise for what very well might be one of the best RPG‚Äôs ever‚Ä¶even if it is tactical.  But one question remains: what on earth possessed me to keep playing, after I had given up for what I thought was the final time? Was it that I felt goaded into continuing by reading all the other glowing reviews? Perhaps. Was it guilt, that somehow I was missing out on something great? Maybe. Was it stubbornness, since I paid full price, I might as well force myself to enjoy the darn thing? Possibly. All of these things could be true, and could be what drew me back in to the world of Rivellon. It could be. But really‚Ä¶really, I think I did it for the cat.

In the begninnng, when the world was dark and formerless, the Elder Bespeckled Ones begot the RPG.  And it was good.  In the years that followed, theys left behind the dice and paper, moving into the realsm of digital wizardry, and in time they did beget the CRPG.  And it was good. A myriad of beardy, stats heavy mana did fall from heaven, and the faithful feasted on Baldurs Gates, Eyes of the Beholders, Neverwinters, Fallouts and Arx Fatalises.    A great time it was, indeed.  A time when quests could be solved by using your brain rather than murdering everything in sight.  A time when putting points into speech resulted in more than just a boost to bartering. A time when you could convince an endgame boss to kill himself if your stats would allow it.  Alas, a time of great darkness followed, and hither came the likes of Dragon Age 2 and Fallout 4, from whence there was little 'role-playing' and simply 'game' in its stead.  Bethesda and Bioware did cheer as they drowned in coin, but the 'R in the 'RPG' was thought lost forever, and the faithful seemed eternally doomed to walk the path of 'action adventures with skills trees but really you just have to murder everything',   'You don't need any of that old beardy old RPG nonsense' Dragin Age Inquisition cried.  'You need bland worlds of endless icons and fetch-questing between awkward digital sex scenes with elven waifus.  You won't have time for meaningful dialogue choices or stats that effect anything other than combat, not when there are farmers who need you to find lost sheep or villagers who need you to go into the forest and bring back10 rumpleberry leaves'.  All was thought lost...   But hark!  the Bespeckled Ones did hear thine prayer!  'A skill-tree doth not an RPG maketh!' cried Larian, and Divinity Original Sin did emerge from the darkenss, and it was good.  It was bloody good. It giveth from the fruits of meaningful dialogue, choices and actions with consequences, stats and character building that actually matter the game, and it blessed with the freedom to solve problems and quests in any way you could figure out.  And in the later years, Larian did beget Divinity Original Sin 2, and it was even better than the first in almost every way imaginable.  More complex, more engaging, more consequential to the players actions, better written, more co opy then before, just more in everyway!  And the faithful did rejoice! Multiple playthroughs were planned, and marriges and careers thrown to the wayside!  It was the RPG we all wanted...  The Bespeckled Ones have not forsaken us.   (FYI this is just a bit of a laugh.  DOS2 is brilliant - get it)

Wow, where do I begin...  This game harkens back to a time long past, a time of unforgiving games that don't hold your hand,  and offers you pithy clues to make your way through a vast uncompromising land replete with challenging combat, the odd puzzle, and a myriad of ways to deal with a situation rather than selecting an option through a chat box.   There were so many instances during my playthrough where I felt like I was breaking quests only to see them to completion in ways that would have involved a reload in others.  It's a game that stands on some firm philosophical foundations: questioning the nature of power, the idea of power corrupting or the good that can be done if consolidated. It explores the nature of institutions in a world gone awry, exemplifying the idea that the road to hell is most certainly paved with good intentions. The moral dilemmas are many, and in an almost Witcheresque fashion, the consequences of actions taken often come with a cost.  That being said, Larian is able to balance the seriousness of the subject with the humor, sarcasm, and satire that they are known for and given the gravity of the events unfolding, the humor adds an extra dimension to the game.  The combat is as challenging as you want it to be. I don't mean in terms of a difficulty slider, I mean in terms of scouring the forums for optimal builds or cheesing for gold to get the best possible equipment. I don't condemn either, I found it rather refreshing that the satisfaction of combat is as customizable as you want it to be depending on how one chooses to engage in a situation. Do you use environmental barrels? Reposition before engaging the situation? Run in and make do? Some of these will work, others will not, but what is interesting is that the solutions to these situations are many and are at the discretion of the player.  The companions you can choose all have excellent backgrounds, some more interesting than others, but all of them were noteworthy. What is also interesting about it is that they are not just there for you, like in most RPGs, they have their own ambitions, goals, and desires and often time going at odds with them could cost you a slot on your roster.   The quests and the world itself are amazing, especially the latter. It's not perfect, and you can clearly see some additional attention was given to certain areas of the game over others, but the different areas, the choices made, and consequences really strengthen the overall story and your journey from a prisoner in Fort Joy to its aftermath.   The quests, in typical Larian fashion, run the gamut. They vary from discovering a serial killer to the occasional rescue to providing an item or eliminating a threat. They are pretty standard fare, but what is interesting is how many different ways you can handle them and the consequences of handling them in the way that you do. There have been bugs with journal entries, and sometimes quests can seem rather baffling, but I didn't really let that upset me. I have no doubt that in the coming months they will be fixed and tightened up. But yeah, to some, and to me at times, it was frustrating.  All in all, this was an excellent game. Perhaps that isn't the right word, it was better than excellent. It was not without its faults, but I really got a lot out of it, from the story, to the challenging combat, the voice acting, the perks and quirks of communing with animals, the different ways to tackle each situation and even the soundtrack. It's a tightly knit rich and rewarding game that you savor long after it ends and even into the beginning of the next playthrough.    If you like CRPGs, you will most likely really see this as a worthy successor to the Fallout 2 style of CRPGs. People have been comparing it to Baldur's Gate 2, and, in terms of the story, companions, and the epic nature of the experience, you can definitely draw comparisons, but the combat is firmly rooted in the Fallout 2 or Temple of Elemental Evil tradition.  So, yeah, Larian does it again, even better than before. I expected a good game, even a great game, but I was not expecting this. It will be penned into the great book of RPG goodness that it deserves. Larian firmly deserves every bit of success they get from this title.   They have stolen the divinity from the former greats and it is perhaps only contested for the crown, in my opinion, by CDPR. Obsidian is also up there, but POE, even in all of its greatness, failed to evoke the same feelings that I had for this. It really filled the void left for me by the Witcher 3, and for those of you that know what I'm talking about and perhaps for those of you reading these reviews to see if it's a worthwhile purchase...it is.  Good luck in your future endeavors Larian, I, for one, will be there to continue to back your projects henceforth, bien fait.

This is my opinion after beating the game on tactician difficulty on coop with friends.  Pros : + Interesting story + High quality voice acting + Beautiful music + Tactical combat + Smooth multiplayer experience + Multiple ways to progress in main quest + Extensive crafting system  Cons : - Awkward camera - Bad difficulty curve (challenging early game, easy mid to late game) - Broken gear stats scaling after early game - Armor system making mixed physical and magical characters less viable - Very buggy endings - Too many puzzles in the last act (I hate puzzles) - Uninteractive blessed/cursed environmental surface in combat (most NPC reapply the effect over and over passively)  Overall : First part of the game is great. Most problems in later part of the game can be fixed or modded. I would still recommend the game for a casual rpg ride.

I would like to preface some things before I start my review: I have been a fan of Larian and their Divine Divinity games since the first game in the series that came out in 2002.  It has taken me 145 hours to complete Divinity Original Sin 2 and I just want to say that it was one of the best CRPG experiences that I have had since I finished Planescape Torment (for the first time) back in 2013.   Now onto the  Pro and Cons followed by my final thoughts.  Pro:   - Interesting story & interesting party members with choice & consequences - Amazing soundtrack - Great replayability (multiple endings, different classes & origins to pursue) - All dialogue is fully voiced (major props to Larian for taking the huge undertaking on fully voicing every line of dialogue in the game) - Robust crafting system - Interactive open world gameplay (picking up objects and moving them around to your advantage or to plan strategies) - Robust character & class customization with the option of respeccing  Cons:  - Optimization issues mainly in the second half of the game/later acts (solved via patches) - Some bugged quests that don't complete properly or don't trigger (solved via patches) - No search item bar option in the inventory for specific items (quality of life improvement)   Conclusion: The sheer amount of content and replayability that you get from this game is staggering and I cannot fathom how Larian have managed to create such an amazing game in such a short span of time (2 years).   I would like to thank Larian and everyone involved including the Kickstarter backers help create this masterpiece. The praise it has received from numerous gaming outlets is well deserved.  Now...do I recommend this game? This is one of those games that shouldn't be missed, because it's one of the best CRPG's ever created and if you have any incling of trying a turn based RPG then I can say without a shadow of a doubt that this game is worth your money.
Just buy it. You can thank me later.

It took me 21 hours to finish the Early Access version of the game and even then I skipped stuff. In the same spirit of games like Baldur's Gate, this game stands out as one of the best RPG's I've played since Witcher 3. I'd easily rank this one right behind Witcher 3 as one of the two best RPG's I've played.  Good: Story with immersive choices, influenced by character, class and background choices ontop of gameplay choices. Rich world with a huge amount of things to do. Meaningful choices, where perks, traits and so on actually have an impact on how you play and even how the story goes. Very high replayability, thanks to all the above. Very pretty to look at and runs excellently.  Bad: Very slow pace, but it's due to the fact that there is so much to do, so much to take in and consider as you progress. Combat can take a long time. Boss fights especially can take a very long time.   Even on the supposed Explorer difficulty mode, I had characters die horribly in combat. I feel that even though this difficulty is meant to be very easy, that it isn't and is still a bit of a challenge. So I can't imagine what the normal difficulty is like.  Some minor spelling errors, but this is EA version so those might be corrected in the full version.  Could be bad, but also good:  Combat can be difficult. You may often need to reload to try a different approach to a fight or to avoid it entirely until you're better prepared. You may progress too quickly into new areas of the game.  There is a TON of dialogue, so if you're the type of person who is impatient and doesn't like reading you might struggle with this game as it's important to read the dialogue.  The deep combat system that involves combining different conditions, applying them correctly, countering them and so on takes a bit of learning but can also make fights drag on. If Divinity: Original Sin is a Messiah-like return to form in open, expansive, story-heavy RPGS, then D:OS2 is the second ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing coming.   Absolutely nothing I've very played can top this game in its gravitas. The story is clever and riveting from the beginning to the end, and keeps the player rabidly invested in the development of both the characters and the state of the world. The story is supported masterfully by the (fully voice acted) dialogue, ambient music, and gorgeous art.   The combat in this game just... makes sense. Veterans of RPG games will have no trouble understanding the system, but even newcomers to the genre can pick it up in the space of a few battles. The game's combat continues to throw you curveballs in terms of player and enemy abilities, but they all fit snugly within the bounds of the overarching system. You'll feel like a strategist, unconsciously planning out the best ways to apply your characters' different abilities to best slay enemies with different armour types and quantities.  Divinity is an apt title for this franchise. The gameplay, story, and aesthetics are all worthy of that mantle. I could honestly see this game as a contender for best RPG of all time.

Scroll to bottom for summary    To start off, I just want to say that I am really enjoying this game quite a bit. I never played the first one and I decided to take a risk for myself by purchasing this because I have not played many turn-based strategy games that I truly enjoyed/got addicted to in the past.  However  this game has me hooked and at the moment I can't think of hardly any reasons as to why I would stop playing it any time soon.    Ok, but why?    Admittedly this game is definitely not for everyone but hopefully this next part will be helpful to someone who is on the fence about it.    You will likely enjoy this game if you...	  (note: These lists are ordered from the most to least impactful on the experience of the game in each category)   Typically enjoy...     ...combat  	  Turn-Based     Strategy     Co-Op     Party-Based     Tactical  Typically enjoy...     ...Genres	  RPG     Adventure     Fantasy     Open-World  Typically enjoy...     ...Styles/Design Choices	  Story Rich     Character Customization     Atmospheric     Great Soundtrack     Click-to-Move     Isometric/Top-Down (Toggleable by player) If you don't fit into any of the items above then this game probably isn't for you but I would still reccomend that you consider purchasing because as I said earlier, I very rarely enjoy Turn-based strategy games but currently I am enjoying this game a lot.  If based on the things mentioned above you think that you  will  like this game, then below is a list of pros & cons.     Pros  (not in any particular order)     In-Depth Character Customization	 (can be re-customized fairly simply without restarting from the beginging of the game)   Very well polished/detailed level design   Engaging and detailed story	  Vibrant atmospheric environments that each have unique characteristics and/or interesting areas to explore	  Great soundtrack that fits the environments very well	  Multiple ways to solve problems/complete quests	  Rarely uses HUD elements to display your objective (immersive)	  (instead of showing your current objective(s) with the HUD, your quests and assignments are told directly to your character by someone you must find and interact with then your objective is writen down in the journal)   Great NPC character voice acting	  Combat system has a very enjoyable amount of depth and skill required to fully master	  Ability to interact with nearly every item/NPC in the game	  It's very easy to just start playing a co-op game and have fun	  Good veriety of enemies, none of the enemies get overused to the point that they feel repetitive	  High resolution textures and shadows to compliment the beautiful variety of environments	  Cons  (likely that some of these are bugs that will be patched later)     Movement is not as elegant and simple as it could be	 (holding mouse1 or panning to the desired location and clicking)   Using the mouse to pan or rotate the camera is jittery and hard to look at even at very high frame rates	  Friendly AI in combat is poor and can make rescuing a friendly NPC in order to complete a quest feel more like a fight against the game and less like a combat scenario   	  Since there are sometimes very few hints as to where you need to go or who you need to talk to in order to complete a quest it can be frustrating to search an area for an extended period of time simply to complete one objective	  Occasional frame drops or inconsistency of frame times / frame rate in certain areas	  Party members sometimes do not move when the leader is moving until you select a different party member to lead, most commonly when changing elevation via a ladder or vine that leads to a part of the level that is currently on-screen	  Summary:	Divinity: Original Sin 2 can provide countless hours of questing, exploring, adventuring, and monster hunting in it's beautifully designed and expansive open-world with countless areas and secrets to find throughout the entire experience which is glued together by a phenomenal soundtrack and wrapped in a cozy blanket of extrodinary storytelling.   Story     10/10   Graphics     9/10   Gameplay     8/10   Sountrack     10/10   OVERALL 92/100  An absolutely amazing game but I had to take a few points off points for the bothersome movement controls and the friendly AI that tries to kill itself when you are trying to save it.

At 16 hours I had had enough: I HATED this game and logged in to write a scathing review. And yet, 160+ hours later, I‚Äôm on my second playthrough, purchased the previous DOS, and am writing a positive review while listening to the OST. What happened?! This whole misunderstanding started with an impulse purchase and a single, overlooked, very tiny, yet crucial word: tactical.  I had finished a turn based RPG and was in the mood for another, when I saw that DOS2 had just been released. I almost never buy a game at launch, but the trailer looked great, Metacritic boasted a ludicrously high score along with dozens of tasty blurbs, and the whole game had that tantalizing sheen that anything new has. The only negative thing I found at the time was a single review that ranted about rage-quitting the game. Who rage-quits a RPG, I thought at the time?  I took a risk, and was immediately entranced: the character creation was complex and intriguing, the opening story and fight sequences were engaging, everything seemed so promising that I hardly noticed the dreaded word I had overlooked earlier. After a while, however, things took a dark turn for the worse. I kept getting beaten, and beaten badly; my frustration mounted; the world was turning against me; nothing was helping; I felt completely powerless‚Ä¶and then‚Ä¶rage quit.  Amidst the guilt, confusion and shame, I decided to sit down and actually read through all those glowing reviews; what was I missing here? And then I finally noticed it, that dreaded word: tactical. I do not play tactical RPG‚Äôs, never have, assumed I never would, and was unprepared for what I was experiencing here. It‚Äôs not that I don‚Äôt play tactical games, but I like to keep my genres separate, and was clearly not expecting this.  I play games for different reasons. Some for immersion, others for adrenaline, mental stimulation, relaxation, storytelling, etc. For me, RPG‚Äôs equal immersion; that‚Äôs what I expect, why I play them. The acts of becoming a character, building them up, leading them through decisions and adventures, customizing them, engaging in their world, these are creative acts. Tactics, on the other hand, are left-brained; strategy; detached, clinical, chess-like, requiring a different mindset. When I crave that, I‚Äôll play a strategy game. But to combine the two is counter to what I want from a role playing experience.  So, after hours of trying really hard to like this game, only to die repeatedly in the process, I had officially given up. This simply wasn‚Äôt for me. Just as I was about to uninstall, though, something happened, and to this day I still don‚Äôt know what it was. For some mysterious reason, I decided to launch DOS2 one last time. I began to play, I mean really play. By the time I finally escaped Fort Joy, I realized something: this game is getting better; a LOT better. And my negative review? Well, suddenly it was becoming a positive one.  It was still no cake-walk, but my feelings began to change when I altered my play style. Up to then I had been approaching it as any other RPG; and it finally sunk in that I simply can‚Äôt do that. I couldn‚Äôt run blindly into battles, dash wildly about the landscape, race through dialogue; instead I had to slow down, take nothing for granted, become obsessed with details. I also had to redefine what it meant to lose. I had to go into each fight knowing my characters wouldn‚Äôt survive, instead using the chance to study the enemies, how they play, how I react, and how it all unfolds, so when I reload, I can play the fight ‚Äúfor real‚Äù and have a plan in mind. This meant that I had to play most battles upwards of half a dozen times before I got it right; but when things did click into place, it was a beautiful feeling.  Still, I do have a few remaining criticisms, the biggest being the quest and map design. Confusing, unforgiving, unhelpful, oblique, unfair‚Ä¶are but a few of the words I‚Äôd use to describe them. Simply put, it‚Äôs just way too easy to stumble into things you‚Äôre not ready for. As for the quests, dialogues and journal entries are misleading, key information is frequently given out of order, or omitted altogether, way too may red-herrings, and the supposed freedom to tackle a quest multiple ways doesn‚Äôt work if you dare to do things out of order. If you‚Äôre looking for guidance, look to Google, for you will find none in-game. People might tout this as a feature: it doesn‚Äôt hold your hand, they cheer. Indeed. There is no hand-holding, which would be fine if the quest design didn‚Äôt keep tripping over its own two feet.  The map layout is so cluttered and dense that basically each and every pixel is trying to kill you. At first I felt this was infuriatingly random; after a while I did start to pick up on the clues, and was able to avoid such missteps, but it was a lesson learned the hard way. There‚Äôs nothing wrong with this, but I‚Äôm used to other games which balance the levels with your current abilities; you can freely wander where you‚Äôre likely to survive, and prevented from getting in over your head. But DOS2 is more than happy to let you get in over your head. The key is to recognize your own limits, knowing the game won‚Äôt do it for you.  As far as audio/visual design, this is single-handedly some of the best art-direction I‚Äôve seen in a game. The detail given to the environments is so rich that the world feels alive in ways that other games could only dream of. Rivellon is LIVED IN; it exists, it‚Äôs lush, and rich in the most unexpected ways. By comparison, all other RPG worlds feel dead, like stage sets populated by mere mannequins. Every square inch of DOS2 is simply bursting with life. The audio is top notch too. I just love the soundtrack. Works brilliantly in game, and is great outside as well. The voices are an absolute treat, too. I don‚Äôt know where they found these actors, but their delivery is infectious. The dialogue is already good, but you can tell how much they really dug their characters, the way they rolled the words around and added such flavor to the lines, making each and every one, from the biggest hero down to the lowest fish monger, feel 100% unique. Seriously, is there an award for best video game ensemble performance?  Regarding immersion, even after coming to terms with a tactical RPG, I was never able to feel that I was part of the world of Rivellon, or that the character I was playing was really me, or that the decisions I made mattered. The story didn‚Äôt haunt me between gaming sessions, I can barely remember most of it now, to be honest. And yet, I‚Äôve had so many individual experiences, so many moments that feel were hand-crafted just for me, so many surprises (both by what I could get away with, and just how flexible the game mechanics really are), that I do feel an emotional, as well as intellectual, connection. This game has given me memories of frustration, true, but also memories of joy, surprise, amazement, wonderment, suspense, excitement, and mischievousness. In spite of the many miraculous accomplishments of this game, it is for these memories that I thank Larian the most.  So now we‚Äôve arrived. That‚Äôs how a sternly negative review, over the course of a few hundred unexpected hours of play, morphed into a shout of praise for what very well might be one of the best RPG‚Äôs ever‚Ä¶even if it is tactical.  But one question remains: what on earth possessed me to keep playing, after I had given up for what I thought was the final time? Was it that I felt goaded into continuing by reading all the other glowing reviews? Perhaps. Was it guilt, that somehow I was missing out on something great? Maybe. Was it stubbornness, since I paid full price, I might as well force myself to enjoy the darn thing? Possibly. All of these things could be true, and could be what drew me back in to the world of Rivellon. It could be. But really‚Ä¶really, I think I did it for the cat.

Very addicting game. There are a lot of freedom in the game, the actions of the player will affect how other npcs act towards the player. Voiced dialogues with decriptive narration as if you are reading a book!   The combat is absolutely amazing especially for those of you that love using magic.  Whenever the player use a spell ie. Rain which will cause the area the leave puddles of water. The player can cast various spell on the water affected area for different status effect.  Casting aerotheurge skills on the water will cause electrocutions, casting poison will turn the water into pools of poison then use fire spells on the poison to release explosions!   There are so many ways of playing inside combat.  At first classic mode may be difficult for players that haven't got use to the game mechanics. One big tip is breaking enemies respective armor (physical/magic armor)  different enemies have different amount, some with lower physical and some with lower magical. Now then you'll have to carefully choose the right character to unleash damage on the enemy with physical or magical damage. Once the armor is broken you are free to put status effects on them to make them more vulnerable or simply crowd control them. Split your party before going in combat! And make uses of line of sight, make the enemy use ap on moving,   This game requires you to plan your strategy ahead, laying a spell and think of what that spell will affect for next few turn.   The world is stopping you from using your most powerful magic! But you hunger to unleash your full strength on to the world. Then this game is for you!

8.5/10  A friend of mine told me about this game and said that I should check it out cause I would probably like it. I didn't check for a week but after some more time I took a look. 10 minutes after first checking out the game I bought it and here I am, almost 100 hours in the game.  The game is huge, we played the first act for 20+ hours, and there are 4 acts! The gameplay is very interactive and feels great, you can, for example, create a puddle of acid and set it ablaze!  EVERYTHING is voice acted and the graphics look beautiful. Also the combat system is great for players that like tactical games. Your positioning and skill usage matter a lot, 1 wrong move might cause the end of you.  There's also a ton of replay value due to all the different classes, origin stories and decisions that you make. On top of that there's the Game Master mode where you can create your own campaign or play the ones from others aswell as the workshop which already has a ton of stuff on it.  The only 2 things that I dislike so far is the fact that a few quests have a tendency to bug out making you unable to complete the quest. Also the mages in this game are kinda underwhelming. Physical characters are much more potent. Im hoping they'll take a look into that.  All in all a great game and possibly one of the best rpgs ive played so far. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes to play rpgs and being able to play this game for months to come.

Amazing game. I was turned off my this game at first because it was a top down game with turn-based combat, which I was never previusly a fan of, but Divinity: Original Sin 2 made me fall in love with it. The story is great and it changes so much depending on what choices you make. The RPG elements in this game are awesome, there are so many different types of roles you can do with so many different elements within each role. This game is a must buy for anyone who loves top down RTS game or even for the people who don't like me.

I'm going to be lazy and post exactly what I posted for D:OS1:  Unsure if extra reviews are needed. This game is a must, it is plain wonderful on all aspects. I cannot possibly imagine the amount of hours it took to fully design and develop this masterpiece. It is one of those games on Steam that put the others to shame. Can be enjoyed immensely alone and with friends. The music is out of this world.

I. Can't. Stop.  Divinity: Original Sin II is a wonderful game. It pulls you into a great world. The combat system is challenging and rewarding. The game is difficult, and as other reviews mention, the game doesn't hold your hand. I've found myself trying to work through problems, and being unable to do so, having to go to a wiki to find answers, only to curse myself afterwards for not seeing the solution.   Everything is delicately crafted. Above all else, everything is connected. An example of this is  at one point in the campaign you find a red ball. Might as well sell it for a couple of gold, right? I decided to hold onto the ball. A few hours later, I came upon a group of dogs that were looking to fight me. One of the options, that wouldn't have been there otherwise, was to toss the ball to the dogs. I did so and avoided combat. You never know where the connections are, and what you can find to help you with different quests. It makes you want to explore every inch of the game, and to come back later to try things differently after you have more insight and experience.  The replay value is tremendous, and I would say mostly attributed to the classes. There are so many different combinations that you can try, as the game lets you build your character how you want to. I have a solo game with 4 playable characters, and I want to try again with trees that I haven't touched and combinations I haven't thought of.  If you are on the fence, and are at least remotely interested in RPGs, buy this game. I'd also note that the first few hours are the hardest, and most discouraging. I imagine this is where those people that quit, or gave this game negative reviews, gave up. People aren't used to this level of freedom, and lack of hand holding from the developers. Learn about the game, and don't be afraid to start a new game after you've grasped the basics.

So now to the D&D section, Thats one of the best features the game can offer right next to the single-player. Would be cool if they would add something like a Waypoint/patrol mode so people are walking around citys, taverns etc.   Battles, Fight's, What can you do SO, the main thing in divinity: Original Sin 2 is the battles, fights, etc.  I tried something harder then easy mode - died. A lot... you are not getting bored in this game... Just a disclaimer, this is my first time playing this type of game. I have never been interested in them, but with all the praise this game has been receiving, I figured I would buy it to try it out. I have been thoroughly impressed with the quality and quantity of the game thus far, especially for the cheaper price tag. The level of complexity with the combat system and crafting is unmatched, I feel like I discover new ways to play the game every few minutes. It can be a difficult game, though that makes it so satisfying when you win a battle. The game doesn't hold your hand, and my friend started out feeling overwhelmed by what we could or couldn't do. The tactical decision making sort of reminds me of Dragon Age: Origins, though more in-depth by far.   Performance is pretty good, there isn't SLI support, though you probably won't need it. The game dropped frames significantly once when surrounded by fire, smoke, gas, and electricity in a high foliage area.   I fully recommend this game if you're even remotely on the fence about it, and I look forward to spending hundreds of hours mastering different classes. The savior of the RPG genre!

I spent over 100 hours on the starting island of Fort Joy completely f*$#ing around and having a blast.  At one point, I collected/stole basically everything I could and just laughed or nodded in respect at the wordplay/detail in the descriptions of each item.  The people at Larian studios clearly put their heart and soul into this game.  I found such absurd ways to circumvent certain situations that I felt sure I'd broken the game... nope that's just Divinity 2, and it's beautiful how it all works together.

This game is everything you could want from a game - Epic, honest, and continually nurtured by the devs (Larian Studios).           DEFINITIVE EDITION - An ACTUAL Definitive-level update, FREE for those who already bought it. Worth it for those that haven't yet bought it..   Divine Ascension DLC. It's a high-quality purchase because:    The Original Soundtrack & Score - Contains all 36 (+1 Bonus Song). So you already know the game is good. Very positive reviews overall and recently. The devs are responsive and sensitive to the players, and it's one of the few Kickstarter projects that didn't seem to fall apart or leave everyone underwhelmed.  What I'd like to do is help you figure out what will leave you perfectly whelmed with this game.  TL;DR? It's tough to get into. I failed the first time. Experiment and mod, and you'll have a blast. The game won't keep you from fights way too tough for you. Just learn caution.  I started it maybe 18 months ago, got to the first town and quit in sort-of frustration. I had approached it all wrong. Maybe I can help others avoid the mistake. Here's what you'll need to know, I think.  This is a game of thought. The action is visceral and fun and frequent (unless you prefer it not to be), but even then you'll be most successful when you are deliberate and creative. Don't expect Dragon Age, this is more complex. Battles aren't about the amount of damage, they're about doing the right damage at the right time. You can see the action order, you can see weaknesses, you can chain things together.  The game is a challenge. Levels are significant. 4 level 10s vs 3 level 11s can be a genuinely tough fight when you're still learning mechanics and combos. Quicksave a lot. Just. Like, constantly. Trust me. It's exhilarating that any encounter can go either way, but you can easily get caught with your skivvies in the static cloud.  Don't be afraid to mod, even on your first play through. I came back after a few mods eased some annoyances and made the game slightly easier, but still a challenge. Just do whatever you need to experience the game, and don't listen to the magisters purists. The strength here is in the play, not the mechanical experience.  You can completely respec at any time, starting in Act 2. No mods needed, total freedom to move all your points. The only thing downside is that you'll have to spend money on skills if you go in a new direction. But even in Act 1, don't fret about getting every level-up right. Try wacky things.  Crafting isn't a chore. Once you know a recipe, you can just make it if you have the stuff. You can experiment like a graveyard debtor without penalty. You can ignore crafting altogether.  Leveling up, getting new equipment, and getting new skills all make an impact. All of them happen often enough that I feel like I'm more powerful in almost every fight. A single level opens up many new options. A new weapon is usually around the corner. A new skill is about to be revealed. Relish it, rookie.  Choices make a difference, not in a superficial way. But there's always a way around. Almost. If there isn't, then that's why you and I will have to play through again. I'm only in Act 2, but I already have a half-dozen things I'd like to see go a different way.  You can make mistakes. I killed a guy I needed because he got‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•that I kept asking the same question. So then I had to work around it. It was great. The devs have you, you can't get yourself into an unbeatable state, but ain't no one gonna slay the voidwoken in the closet for you. Also, if you have an undead, always check their coverings or disguise. Just sayin'. Poor townspersons.  Do you like "gaming the game?" Figuring out what's overpowered and exploiting it? Go for it! Me, I think that's as boring as a turtle's unrequited love laments, so if you're like me don't read a thing about min-maxing or party makeup. Just pick what you like and you can make it work and the work to do so won't be so bad because it's fun.  If you expect Diablo or Dragon Age, a one-best-way game or mindless distraction, this isn't it. I dig all of those, but this game isn't what I play to scratch those itches.  Oh, and teleport is a crazy useful skill. Make sure at least 1 person has it. FIN.

I would like to preface some things before I start my review: I have been a fan of Larian and their Divine Divinity games since the first game in the series that came out in 2002.  It has taken me 145 hours to complete Divinity Original Sin 2 and I just want to say that it was one of the best CRPG experiences that I have had since I finished Planescape Torment (for the first time) back in 2013.   Now onto the  Pro and Cons followed by my final thoughts.  Pro:   - Interesting story & interesting party members with choice & consequences - Amazing soundtrack - Great replayability (multiple endings, different classes & origins to pursue) - All dialogue is fully voiced (major props to Larian for taking the huge undertaking on fully voicing every line of dialogue in the game) - Robust crafting system - Interactive open world gameplay (picking up objects and moving them around to your advantage or to plan strategies) - Robust character & class customization with the option of respeccing  Cons:  - Optimization issues mainly in the second half of the game/later acts (solved via patches) - Some bugged quests that don't complete properly or don't trigger (solved via patches) - No search item bar option in the inventory for specific items (quality of life improvement)   Conclusion: The sheer amount of content and replayability that you get from this game is staggering and I cannot fathom how Larian have managed to create such an amazing game in such a short span of time (2 years).   I would like to thank Larian and everyone involved including the Kickstarter backers help create this masterpiece. The praise it has received from numerous gaming outlets is well deserved.  Now...do I recommend this game? This is one of those games that shouldn't be missed, because it's one of the best CRPG's ever created and if you have any incling of trying a turn based RPG then I can say without a shadow of a doubt that this game is worth your money.

I'll start by saying i've not played all that far through the story - I've had multiple starts due to purchasing just prior to release and a Co-op partner who seems to enjoy playing several classes before sticking to one.   Interestingly enough, this has had the positive of showing me just how different the game can be with different class combinations. We've played combos where it seems that no matter how careful we are, the battlefield inevitably becomes a blanket of different elemental affects indiscriminately maiming everybody on it and we've had more tactical groups that have more control over such affects, without the volatile power behind their attacks.   We've settled on a slightly more understated group, methodically using status affects to control the flow of battle and tip it into our favour.   The game is beautiful looking, it's as deep as you wish it to be and the sheer amount of detail in the world is amazing. The UI is simple without being restrictive, the game will guide you without holding your hand and through that allows you to make your mistakes, or genius discoveries and whichever it be, you're left with under no illusion: That was your doing, for better or worse.   I always want to like games like this but often find the world doesn't feel alive enough, is to linear or awkwardly open to its own detriment - the balance is never quite right, but here, for me at least it has been struck and i've really enjoyed exploring and experimenting.   tldr:   The game is generally well polished, fun and of good depth. Looks beautiful, with an interesting story and the world feels richer for it. Worth a buy from any RPG fan, especially if like me, an rpg feeling like an MMO with no players in it just feels like an empty experience to you - you wont find that here.

In my experance any way the game's turn based mechancis wont adversly impact your enjoyment in any way, if anything you may find you like it if only in this specific case. As to the story, world and characters they are all master strokes through and through, the massive array of options and granular details to game give it huge replayability just in terms of the main campaign and the community have added a lot more via mods and scenarios. Put simply you will get your monies worth out of this game just from the stock content then on top of that you have a great community giving you even more via Workshop and Nexus.  Cons? My personal Review to Divinity: Original Sin 2 So, lets get this straight, this game is a master-piece.   It's a game like XCOM: Enemy Unkown its a game like The Witcher its a game like Dragon Age and many more...  Divinity is not for everyone, but it is for everyone who loves MMO/RPG/TBG Turn based game I try to be spoiler free, but i will include stuff in this review that is obvious.  Character Editor There are a few thing's that i want to talk about, mostly good. You can create your own char in this game, and it's not only for the look, it changes the gameplay for the entire game. There are a few races, Human's, Lizard's, Drawf's, Skeleton's, Elf's... Every Race has a unique talent, example: Elf's can eat body Part's and know what happened to them or what they thought about while they died, sound strange? Yes it is. But it help's you in-game to find hidden treasures or hidden quest's. Even the NPC's are reacting to your Gender/Race/Behavior.  You can choose your own Style, i dont mean hair, face, etc. i mean... how your char is reacting to things... example: I mad a Noble Lizard, that talk's like it has a stick up her‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• I role-play her like she is a Annoying know-it-all.  This way, your story takes different out comes. So watch out what you pick.  The only thing that bugs me is, that i cant change how tall my char is, how the body looks... Also, some gear looks weird on the body of the chars, they look more fat in some of these, and some are way to skimpy.  There are also many trait's and Skills you can pick but thats too much to go in to... You just need to know one think... there is everything from the normal knight to cleric.  This might be a spoiler for an enemy in the game: Some races has permanent side effects.. like skeletons heal when they get poison damage, same with enemys Martin Looter King What can i say? There is a‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•tone of loot... i dont know how much and how different they are, but what i saw so far... simply -amazing-  I just noticed, here and there, some clothing and loot looks the same... different item stats, but what will you do with a such big game?  The Trading is very simple to use, easy to access, quick to understand.   Enemy's you face NPC's Sadly, this is the only point i am slighty disappointed, its not bad for me, but i think some people might notice very quickly, that there are not that many different enemy types. Yes there are plenty, but for the length of this game, it might get boring. I dont mean the fights, i mean the types, i go to the fights after this section...  Oh boy... the NPC's... Where do i start? Simply put, they all are very good written, +1 to the writer's. They never get boring, it feels like every NPC has a story... also, they all are voiced, but sometimes here and there, they dont speak, mostly for stuff like "YOU THERE! You violated the law! Return your goods or serve your sentence!"  But still, its amazing how much time they put in to the voice acting... and the Narrator... gosh, very good job... you mostly hear his voice, he is describing EVERYTHING you see, smell, feel, do. Its truly amazing.  Sometimes you hear the same voice actor from another person... but this is not a biggy. They did the same in Oblivion, but i dont mind, some people do but not me, a simple little thing.   Multiplayer / Co-op / D&D Mode Alright, lets make this one short, There  is the PvP in alpha/beta, quite fun, then you are able to play the WHOLE Story with 3 others... other player. It's super fun, but i recommend to play with someone you know or to scream at... if you play with randoms... they attack the guard... many... times... its a pain in the‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Sometimes people dont do that, but many do...  So now to the D&D section, Thats one of the best features the game can offer right next to the single-player. I recommend not to access the Game Master Mode, many spoilers there, enemy types, loot etc.  It's hard to describe, but all you need to know, its like a level editor, or like that one thing from Arma 3 Zeus mode. You can role Dice, you can possess NPC's you can do all kind of‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• But... you need to do all by your self. That means, no NPC's walking around, only you, moving people from A to b. Would be cool if they would add something like a Waypoint/patrol mode so people are walking around citys, taverns etc.   Battles, Fight's, What can you do SO, the main thing in divinity: Original Sin 2 is the battles, fights, etc.  I tried something harder then easy mode - died. You need some training in the beginning but you will find a way to deal with different enemy types and 'areas'.  By Area, i mean... You surrounding. There are some different types of 'things' laying around... Let's talk about the basic of the basic, Fire we all know it, we all hate it. You can ignite Oil with fire, you can throw oil at enemy's, you can burn an enemy and lead him in to a puddle of oil so they explode in a cool way. There are some other thinks like Water and wetness, combined with electricity... just try stuff... its super fun to combine these elements... you can also use magic to make it cursed ;)  My RatingAre there Physic's / Ragdoll in the game? - Yas How big is the map?                                   - Very big, much to explore How are the graphic's?                               - Very nice, smooth pleasent to watch people burn or acid away Fighting?                                                     - Very good, sometimes its too easy, sometimes its too hard, or just ged gud. Multiplayer?                                                - Everything works good, no disconnect stuff or lagging. Plenty of people are                                                                         playing this game Stuff to do?                                                 - Yas... A lot... you are not getting bored in this game... Replay potential?                                       - I think you could play this game like 30 times and you still wouldnt find everything in                                                this game, many secrets, many options, combine race/trait's and you will have a different out come Is it buy worthy? Yes! 100% but ONLY when you are a fan of TBG/MMO/RPG's video games. A few games as example:  XCOM: Enemy unknown Dragon Age The Witcher Mass EffectThere are just a hand full of good MMORPG's out there, and if you like turn based combat, then its the perfect game for you, you can waste so many hours in this game, finding the best way to solve problems without fighting. The combat is pure turn based strategy, and while cheesable, can be quite difficult while rewarding smart tactics.  The story is enthralling, as are each of the dozens of side stories. I'm hesitant to label them quests, as I feel that would demean their stature in some way.  Finally, the sound track is amazing. So good in fact, that it won't stop playing on loop in my head, even when I wish it would because I've been up for 46 hours and please let me sleep.  10/10, will play again once I can convince a friend to get the game for a co-op playthrough.

My personal Review to Divinity: Original Sin 2 So, lets get this straight, this game is a master-piece.   It's a game like XCOM: Enemy Unkown its a game like The Witcher its a game like Dragon Age and many more...  Divinity is not for everyone, but it is for everyone who loves MMO/RPG/TBG Turn based game I try to be spoiler free, but i will include stuff in this review that is obvious.  Character Editor There are a few thing's that i want to talk about, mostly good. You can create your own char in this game, and it's not only for the look, it changes the gameplay for the entire game. There are a few races, Human's, Lizard's, Drawf's, Skeleton's, Elf's... Every Race has a unique talent, example: Elf's can eat body Part's and know what happened to them or what they thought about while they died, sound strange? Yes it is. But it help's you in-game to find hidden treasures or hidden quest's. Even the NPC's are reacting to your Gender/Race/Behavior.  You can choose your own Style, i dont mean hair, face, etc. i mean... how your char is reacting to things... example: I mad a Noble Lizard, that talk's like it has a stick up her‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• I role-play her like she is a Annoying know-it-all.  This way, your story takes different out comes. So watch out what you pick.  The only thing that bugs me is, that i cant change how tall my char is, how the body looks... Also, some gear looks weird on the body of the chars, they look more fat in some of these, and some are way to skimpy.  There are also many trait's and Skills you can pick but thats too much to go in to... You just need to know one think... there is everything from the normal knight to cleric.  This might be a spoiler for an enemy in the game: Some races has permanent side effects.. like skeletons heal when they get poison damage, same with enemys Martin Looter King What can i say? There is a‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•tone of loot... i dont know how much and how different they are, but what i saw so far... simply -amazing-  I just noticed, here and there, some clothing and loot looks the same... different item stats, but what will you do with a such big game?  The Trading is very simple to use, easy to access, quick to understand.   Enemy's you face NPC's Sadly, this is the only point i am slighty disappointed, its not bad for me, but i think some people might notice very quickly, that there are not that many different enemy types. Yes there are plenty, but for the length of this game, it might get boring. I dont mean the fights, i mean the types, i go to the fights after this section...  Oh boy... the NPC's... Where do i start? Simply put, they all are very good written, +1 to the writer's. They never get boring, it feels like every NPC has a story... also, they all are voiced, but sometimes here and there, they dont speak, mostly for stuff like "YOU THERE! You violated the law! Return your goods or serve your sentence!"  But still, its amazing how much time they put in to the voice acting... and the Narrator... gosh, very good job... you mostly hear his voice, he is describing EVERYTHING you see, smell, feel, do. Its truly amazing.  Sometimes you hear the same voice actor from another person... but this is not a biggy. They did the same in Oblivion, but i dont mind, some people do but not me, a simple little thing.   Multiplayer / Co-op / D&D Mode Alright, lets make this one short, There  is the PvP in alpha/beta, quite fun, then you are able to play the WHOLE Story with 3 others... other player. It's super fun, but i recommend to play with someone you know or to scream at... if you play with randoms... they attack the guard... many... times... its a pain in the‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Sometimes people dont do that, but many do...  So now to the D&D section, Thats one of the best features the game can offer right next to the single-player. I recommend not to access the Game Master Mode, many spoilers there, enemy types, loot etc.  It's hard to describe, but all you need to know, its like a level editor, or like that one thing from Arma 3 Zeus mode. You can role Dice, you can possess NPC's you can do all kind of‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• But... you need to do all by your self. That means, no NPC's walking around, only you, moving people from A to b. Would be cool if they would add something like a Waypoint/patrol mode so people are walking around citys, taverns etc.   Battles, Fight's, What can you do SO, the main thing in divinity: Original Sin 2 is the battles, fights, etc.  I tried something harder then easy mode - died. You need some training in the beginning but you will find a way to deal with different enemy types and 'areas'.  By Area, i mean... You surrounding. There are some different types of 'things' laying around... Let's talk about the basic of the basic, Fire we all know it, we all hate it. You can ignite Oil with fire, you can throw oil at enemy's, you can burn an enemy and lead him in to a puddle of oil so they explode in a cool way. There are some other thinks like Water and wetness, combined with electricity... just try stuff... its super fun to combine these elements... you can also use magic to make it cursed ;)  My RatingAre there Physic's / Ragdoll in the game? - Yas How big is the map?                                   - Very big, much to explore How are the graphic's?                               - Very nice, smooth pleasent to watch people burn or acid away Fighting?                                                     - Very good, sometimes its too easy, sometimes its too hard, or just ged gud. Multiplayer?                                                - Everything works good, no disconnect stuff or lagging. Plenty of people are                                                                         playing this game Stuff to do?                                                 - Yas... A lot... you are not getting bored in this game... Replay potential?                                       - I think you could play this game like 30 times and you still wouldnt find everything in                                                this game, many secrets, many options, combine race/trait's and you will have a different out come Is it buy worthy? Yes! 100% but ONLY when you are a fan of TBG/MMO/RPG's video games. A few games as example:  XCOM: Enemy unknown Dragon Age The Witcher Mass EffectThere are just a hand full of good MMORPG's out there, and if you like turn based combat, then its the perfect game for you, you can waste so many hours in this game, finding the best way to solve problems without fighting. Divinity has always been a great fantasy IP from the first through the Dragon Knight saga and now in Original Sin.   I am not usually a big fan of turn based combat and that might give people cause to pause when considering this game, it did with me anyway .... dont let that stop you though.   This is a true role playing game something we see so very rarely these days, the turn based mechanic of the combat wont get in your way. In my experance any way the game's turn based mechancis wont adversly impact your enjoyment in any way, if anything you may find you like it if only in this specific case. As to the story, world and characters they are all master strokes through and through, the massive array of options and granular details to game give it huge replayability just in terms of the main campaign and the community have added a lot more via mods and scenarios. Put simply you will get your monies worth out of this game just from the stock content then on top of that you have a great community giving you even more via Workshop and Nexus.  Cons? Nothing really, while the game isn't perfect ... simply because nothing is ... there is nothing I would see changed about it that isn't a matter of personal taste and for thouse aspects of taste the community has that covered in mods e.g. difficulty rebalance, spell effects, rate of progression, etc.

I've played all the games in the Divinity series several times over, I'm a fan of their work so, it's possible that my review is not entirely objective. Because Original Sin was such an amazing game, I've followed the progress of its successor's development and watched how Larian, with the help of the community, turned Original Sin 2 into an even better game.  The freedom you have in Original Sin 2 while exploring and the way you're progressing through the game is some of the best I've seen. It gave me mixed feelings of excitement and nostalgia which, at times, made me forget that I'm in the year 2017, and feel the same way that I did while playing Torment or Fallout. It felt new and enticing, the areas are varied and the content is hidden behind actually talking with people or having to read stuff to know what to do. You can mess up and miss out on quests if you kill people and your actions have consequences, I know, I killed everyone in a playtrough. NPC's are not immortal just because they have a generic quest attached to them.  If you're unsure on whether to purchase the game or not, I'll try to help.  PROS: - Varied, visual detailed and beautiful areas. No recycled content (like Generic caves 1 to 40 in Dragon Age 2); - Detailed origin stories that have an effect over multiple encounters in the game; - Fully and adequately voice acted(Apart from 1-2 encounters); - Lots of class combinations and spell interactions; - Extremely satisfying combat; - Level-dependent loot system; - Loads of exploration; - Puzzles; - A plethora of quests, fun ones; - Excellent writing; - Interesting and useful crafting system; - Actions/Consequences; - You can follow your own path and still achieve the endgame; - It does not have the price of an AAA title, it's only 45 euros and offers far more content than its competitors.  CONS:  - In the first few days the game seemed a bit rushed, there's still room for improvements/optimizations; - Using more resources than Mass Effect: Andromeda/ The Witcher 3 on Ultra seems a bit of an overkill; - Found a few placeholder items and unfinished areas; - Difficulties do not make enemies smarter or, at least, they don't appear to be doing it. It's just hp/armor/damage multiplier; - Entire difficult fights can be won instantly; - Sending items to party members is not proximity based; - Pruned talent trees compared to Original Sin;  Few of Today's companies have the dedication and experience to release a polished and entertaining product that offers huge amounts of content at such a low cost. Well, Larian did it. They released decent content in the past but their latest games have shown a huge level of interest in their users, the feedback they provide and they genuinely seemed to care about their work. I can't wait for your next game, keep up the good work guys!

If I am being honest, I will start by saying that Divinity: Original Sin didn‚Äôt grab me in quite the same way it so obviously did many others. I saw a lot of merit to its combat, flexible quests and vibrant presentation, but thought the lack of direction, both from a narrative and gameplay standpoint, alongside some tonal issues, were sore points that kept me from really breaking into it. Several years later and Larian Studios have done just what I hoped they would, making a sequel that retains the strengths of previous game while addressing just about every issue I had with it, and then going even further with additions like full voice acting, something not generally found in the recent wave of cRPG games. Due to the relatively high difficulty and patience required it may still not be for everybody, but Divinity: Original Sin 2 is very much at the pinnacle of the sub-genre and will no doubt prove intoxicating for those who get trapped in its spell.   continue reading [www.newgamenetwork.com]

No need to repeat what everyone else has said, except to say that the modding scene should be much more improved and supported than the first game. I wouldn't expect skyrim level modding, but there's a ton of potential for gameplay overhauls and new content, never mind a possibly revolutionary game master mode, if that sort of thing compells you to buy a game. Many of the criticisms regarding balance and difficulty could be solved by modders in the first couple months. Heck, many aspects of the game are already moddable, though obviously it'd be a bit silly to mod an alpha.  Barring a large drop in quality in the later acts (extremely unlikely), this will probably be an instant classic with amazing RPG gameplay that far surpasses its predecessor in narrative quality.  I will say Larian could be a bit more generous with more skills for us to play with in the alpha, but let me tell you, from what I've seen, there are going to be a LOT more cool skills in the final release. ;)

I'm not going to get into great detail about any of this, i'm not professional reviewer, but I'm going to adress some things that are pretty important to me when deciding whether or not to buy a game:  Is it worth getting this game in early access? - In my opinion, as a big fan of this genre, yes There is probably 10-13 hours of content if you try to do EVERYTHING. More content to be added such as New playable undead race, more origin stories, new areas to explore etc. There is so much content coming and so much that I missed out on as well. there are a few bugs. keep that in mind.   How is it mechanically to the first Original Sin? - A drastically better inventory system, skill system seems to be much deeper, and there is a bit more variety in ways to play as each skill point provides some kind of bonus besides just allowing you to use higher level skills IE: Necromancy gives you lifesteal, or Hunstman reduces the penalty for firing from low ground gives a bonus for attacking from high ground etc. etc.  Bugs?  - Yes, a few that really stuck out: Blank Conversation boxes that require a reload to escape from, quests unable to be complete even with all the items in your inventory, and smaller ones like ressurecting a character but instead of standing up they slide around the ground. These kinds of things are 100% expected in early access so avoid this game if you aren't willing to try to squash them.  How is the Story?  - Personally I find it much more engaging this time around. As a Sourceror there is a lot more room to be the bad guy if you would prefer it. In the first one it didn't make much sense to be an Evil Source hunter. I don't want to spoil anything at all but there were a lot of moments, even in side quests, that I thought were really cool. Some kinda sad stuff too with the Pet Pal Talent (Which lets you talk to animals).  Overall, I found it to be very worthwhile. I am excited to see new content added and bugs fixed as time goes by. So far, Larian is really knocking it out of the park.   TL;DR: I really enjoyed it. It is not yet complete. IF you're a fan of isometric or old-school RPGs this game is for you. Co-Op is fun. Skill system is neato. If you want a super complete experience this is not the game for you. Hope this helped someone!
